name: Swords, sandals and lightning bolts
description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, Russell Crowe plays one of the most recogniseable gods in the pantheon – Zeus. His scenes lampoon his Oscar-winning role in Gladiator, one of the most recognised films in a classic genre.

key_work.title: Zeus costume and lightning bolt
key_work.brief_description:
Thor Love and Thunder introduces Russell Crowe as Zeus, the legendary king of the gods. Like Thor (Chris Hemsworth), Zeus’ hero armour is bold and bright, emphasising his supernatural qualities. His burnished gold breastplate and swaggering confidence make it clear that he is a god who is used to being admired – perhaps a bit too used to it.

Unlike Thor, Zeus has been filling his days with excess, basking in the attention of the lesser gods in the Grand Pantheon, seemingly unmotivated to track down Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale). While his hero armour looks heroic on the battlefield, in the context of his decadent, easy lifestyle at the start of the film, the extravagance makes him look less like a living legend, and more like a man who is resting on his extremely golden laurels.

links.description: Crowe won an Oscar as general-turned-gladiator Maximus in Ridley Scott’s epic. In Thor: Love and Thunder he wears a breastplate that recalls the role. Chris Hemsworth (Thor) commented that he never thought he’d see Crowe on screen ‘with hints at Gladiator imagery, yet with a wink’.

end.title: The Fall of the Roman Empire
end.creator_credit: Anthony Mann, Samuel Bronston and Samuel Bronston Productions
end.brief_description: In second century Rome Emperor Marcus Aurelius plans to make the heir to the throne his adopted son Livius, rather than his biological son Commodus. Indignant with rage, Commodus has his father murdered and succeeds him, declaring himself a God. When Commodus discovers that his sister, Lucilla has a stronger claim to the throne than he, Commodus sentences her to burn at the stake. This sword-and-sandal epic harked back to successful 1950s biblical dramas with its lavish sets, scores of extras, remarkable action sequences and a chariot race. The exorbitant cost of the film (and poor audience reception) financially ruined producer Samuel Bronston. It has been speculated that audiences were tiring of such lavish productions and timing may have also hurt the film’s box-office - it was released the same year as the opulent Burton/Taylor epic “Cleopatra”. Cast includes Sophia Loren, Christopher Plummer, Alec Guinness, Omar Sharif and James Mason.

end.title: Monty Python's life of Brian [DVD]
end.creator_credit: Terry Jones, John Goldstone and HandMade Films
end.brief_description: Iconic comedy from the Monty Python team, “The Life of Brian” ridicules Christianity, organised religion, politics, underground subversives and Jesus Christ. From birth, the unfortunate and guileless Brian is mistaken for the Son of God and dogged by his nearby presence as well as being pestered by his shrewish mother. The Monty Python crew each play numerous roles within the film, creating an anarchic madcap spoof of Biblical films and religious epics. With several musical interludes, including “Always look on the bright side of life” (sung at the crucifixion) the writers slay many sacred cows in the name of comedy. Blissfully sacrilegious and completely irreverent, “Life of Brian” was banned in several countries, but nevertheless garnered cult status and is regarded by many as the funniest of the Monty Python’s feature films. Also features Spike Milligan and Beatle George Harrison, whose company produced the film.

links.description: The climactic scene of Spartacus features the recaptured slaves claiming “I’m Spartacus!”, when asked to identify the gladiator leader. The famous line was inverted and parodied in Monty Python’s Life of Brian, where captured prisoners claim, “I’m Brian!” to be pardoned.

start.title: Samson and Delilah
start.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille and Paramount Pictures
start.brief_description: Cecil B. De Mille’s famous epic style is highlighted in this classic bible story about the legendary strongman Samson and the temptress Delilah, who helped destroy him. Lauded for its lush cinematography, performances, costumes, sets and special effects, it was a box office smash.
